arguments.description: Specifies that the initial step-size value aⁿ (where n=0) for each line search (used by the QUANEW, CONGRA, or NEWRAP technique) cannot be larger than r times the step-size value used in the former iteration.

arguments.name: FCONV2=
arguments.description: Specifies a second function convergence criterion.

arguments.name: FCONV=
arguments.description: Specifies the relative function convergence criterion.

arguments.name: FSIZE=
arguments.description: Specifies the FSIZE parameter of the relative function and relative gradient termination criteria. The default value is r=0.

arguments.name: GCONV2=
arguments.description: Specifies another relative gradient convergence criterion.

arguments.name: GCONV=
arguments.description: Specifies the relative gradient convergence criterion.

arguments.name: HESCAL=
arguments.description: Specifies the scaling version of the Hessian or crossproduct Jacobian matrix used in NRRIDG, TRUREG, LEVMAR, NEWRAP, or DBLDOG optimization.
Specifies that no scaling is done.
Specifies the Moré (1978) scaling update
Specifies the Dennis, Gay, and Welsch (1981) scaling update
Specifies that di is reset in each iteration

arguments.name: INHESSIAN
arguments.description: Specifies how the initial estimate of the approximate Hessian is defined for the quasi-Newton techniques QUANEW and DBLDOG.

arguments.name: INSTEP=
arguments.description: Reduces the length of the first trial step during the line search of the first iterations.

arguments.name: LCDEACT=
arguments.description: Specifies a threshold r for the Lagrange multiplier that decides whether an active inequality constraint remains active or can be deactivated.

arguments.name: LCEPSILON=
arguments.description: Specifies the range r, r ≥ 0, for active and violated boundary and linear constraints.

arguments.name: LCSINGULAR=
arguments.description: Specifies a criterion r, r ≥ 0, used in the update of the QR decomposition that decides whether an active constraint is linearly dependent on a set of other active constraints.

arguments.name: LINESEARCH=
arguments.description: Specifies the line-search method for the CONGRA, QUANEW, and NEWRAP optimization techniques.

Specifies a line-search method that needs the same number of function and gradient calls for cubic interpolation and cubic extrapolation; this method is similar to one used by the Harwell subroutine library.

Specifies a line-search method that needs more function calls than gradient calls for quadratic and cubic interpolation and cubic extrapolation; this method is implemented as shown in Fletcher (1987) and can be modified to an exact line search by using the LSPRECISION= option.

Specifies a line-search method that needs the same number of function and gradient calls for cubic interpolation and cubic extrapolation; this method is implemented as shown in Fletcher (1987) and can be modified to an exact line search by using the LSPRECISION= option.
Specifies a line-search method that needs the same number of function and gradient calls for stepwise extrapolation and cubic interpolation
Specifies a line-search method that is a modified version of LIS=4.
Specifies golden section line search (Polak 1971), which uses only function values for linear approximation.
Specifies bisection line search (Polak 1971), which uses only function values for linear approximation.
Specifies Armijo line-search technique (Polak 1971), which uses only function values for linear approximation.

arguments.name: LSPRECISION=
arguments.description: Specifies the degree of accuracy that should be obtained by the line-search algorithms LIS=2 and LIS=3. The default LSPRECISION= values are:

arguments.name: MAXFUNC=
arguments.description: Requires the number of function calls to be no larger than i. The default values are:

arguments.name: MAXITER=
arguments.description: Requires the number of iterations to be no larger than i. The default values are: o For TECH= LEVMAR, NEWRAP, NRRIDG, TRUREG: i=50 o For TECH= DBLDOG, QUANEW: i=200 o For TECH= CONGRA: i=400

arguments.name: MAXSTEP=
arguments.description: Specifies an upper bound for the step length of the line-search algorithms during the first n iterations.

arguments.name: MAXTIME=
arguments.description: Requires the CPU time to be no larger than r. The default value of the MAXTIME= option is the largest double floating-point number on your computer.

arguments.name: MINITER=
arguments.description: Specifies the minimum number of iterations. The default value is 0.

arguments.name: MSINGULAR=
arguments.description: Specifies a relative singularity criterion r, r > 0, for the inversion of the information matrix, which is needed to compute the covariance matrix.

arguments.name: NOPRINT
arguments.description: Suppresses output related to optimization such as the iteration history.

arguments.name: PALL
arguments.description: [Displays information about the starting values and final values of the optimization process.

arguments.name: PHISTORY
arguments.description: Displays the optimization history. The PHISTORY option is set automatically if the PALL or PRINT option is set.

arguments.name: RESTART=
arguments.description: Specifies that the QUANEW or CONGRA algorithm is restarted with a steepest descent/ascent search direction after at most i iterations, i > 0.

arguments.name: SINGULAR=
arguments.description: Specifies the singularity criterion r, 0 < r < 1, used, for example, for matrix inversion.

arguments.name: SOCKET=
arguments.description: Specifies the fileref that contains the information needed for remote monitoring.

arguments.name: TECHNIQUE=
arguments.description: Specifies the optimization technique.
arguments.help: TECHNIQUE=CONGRA | DBLDOG | LEVMAR | NEWRAP | NRRIDG | QUANEW | TRUREG | NONE

arguments.name: CONGRA
arguments.description: Chooses one of four different conjugate-gradient optimization algorithms, which can be more precisely defined with the UPDATE= option and modified with the LINESEARCH= option.

arguments.name: DBLDOG
arguments.description: Performs a version of double-dogleg optimization, which uses the gradient to update an approximation of the Cholesky factor of the Hessian.

arguments.name: LEVMAR
arguments.description: Performs a highly stable but, for large problems, memory- and time-consuming Levenberg-Marquardt optimization technique, a slightly improved variant of the Moré (1978) implementation. This is the default optimization technique if there are fewer than 40 parameters to estimate.

arguments.name: NEWRAP
arguments.description: Performs a usually stable but, for large problems, memory- and time-consuming Newton-Raphson optimization technique. The algorithm combines a line-search algorithm with ridging, and it can be modified with the LINESEARCH= option.

arguments.name: NRRIDG
arguments.description: Performs a usually stable but, for large problems, memory- and time-consuming Newton-Raphson optimization technique. This algorithm does not perform a line search.

arguments.name: QUANEW
arguments.description: Chooses one of four different quasi-Newton optimization algorithms that can be more precisely defined with the UPDATE= option and modified with the LINESEARCH= option.

arguments.name: TRUREG
arguments.description: Performs a usually very stable but, for large problems, memory- and time-consuming trust-region optimization technique. The algorithm is implemented similar to Gay (1983) and Moré and Sorensen (1983).

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Does not perform any optimization. This option is similar to METHOD=NONE, but TECH=NONE also computes and displays residuals and goodness of fit statistics.

arguments.name: UPDATE=
arguments.description: Specifies the update method for the quasi-Newton, double-dogleg, or conjugate-gradient optimization technique.
arguments.help: UPDATE=BFGS | DBFGS | DDFP | DFP | PB | FR | PR | CD

arguments.name: BFGS
arguments.description: Performs the original Broyden, Fletcher, Goldfarb, and Shanno (BFGS) update of the inverse Hessian matrix.

arguments.name: DBFGS
arguments.description: Performs the dual BFGS update of the Cholesky factor of the Hessian matrix. This is the default update method.

arguments.name: DDFP
arguments.description: Performs the dual Davidon, Fletcher, and Powell (DFP) update of the Cholesky factor of the Hessian matrix.

arguments.name: DFP
arguments.description: Performs the original DFP update of the inverse Hessian matrix.

arguments.name: PB
arguments.description: Performs the automatic restart update method of Powell (1977) and Beale (1972).

arguments.name: FR
arguments.description: Performs the Fletcher-Reeves update (Fletcher 1987).

arguments.name: PR
arguments.description: Performs the Polak-Ribiere update (Fletcher 1987).

arguments.name: CD
arguments.description: Performs a conjugate-descent update of Fletcher (1987).

arguments.name: VERSION=
arguments.description: Specifies the version of the quasi-Newton optimization technique with nonlinear constraints.
Specifies the update of the U vector as in Powell (1978a, 1978b) (update like VF02AD).
Specifies the update of the U vector as in Powell (1982a, 1982b) (update like VMCWD).

arguments.name: VSINGULAR=
arguments.description: Specifies a relative singularity criterion r, r > 0, for the inversion of the information matrix, which is needed to compute the covariance matrix.

arguments.name: XCONV=
arguments.description: Specifies the relative parameter convergence criterion. Termination requires a small relative parameter change in subsequent iterations.

arguments.name: XSIZE=
arguments.description: Specifies the XSIZE parameter of the relative function and relative gradient termination criteria. The default value is r=0.

statements.name: OUTPUT
statements.description: where: keyword<(keyword-options)> <=name> specifies a statistic to include in the output data set and optionally assigns the variable the name, name. You can use the keyword-options to control which type of a particular statistic to compute. The keyword-options can take on the following values: BLUP uses the predictors of the random effects in computing the statistic. ILINK computes the statistic on the scale of the data. NOBLUP does not use the predictors of the random effects in computing the statistic. NOILINK computes the statistic on the scale of the link function. The default is to compute statistics by using BLUPs on the scale of the link function (the linearized scale).

arguments.name: LCL=
arguments.description: Outputs the following statistic: LCL<=name> Lower prediction limit for linear predictor; default variable name: "LCL" LCL(NOBLUP)<=name> Lower confidence limit for marginal linear predictor; default variable name: "LCLPA" LCL(ILINK)<=name> Lower prediction limit for mean; default variable name: "LCLMu"

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: Specifies the name of the output data set.

arguments.name: PEARSON=
arguments.description: Outputs the following statistic: PEARSON<=name> Pearson-type residual; default variable name: "Pearson" PEARSON(NOBLUP)<=name> Marginal Pearson-type residual; default variable name: "PearsonPA"

arguments.name: PREDICTED=
arguments.description: Outputs the following statistic: PREDICTED<=name> Linear predictor; default variable name: "Pred" PREDICTED(NOBLUP)<=name> Marginal linear predictor; default variable name: "PredPA" PREDICTED(ILINK)<=name> Predicted mean; default variable name: "PredMu"

arguments.name: RESIDUAL=
arguments.description: Outputs the following statistic: RESIDUAL<=name> Residual; default variable name: "Resid" RESIDUAL(NOBLUP)<=name> Marginal residual; default variable name: "ResidPA" RESIDUAL(ILINK)<=name> Residual on mean scale; default variable name: "ResidMu"

arguments.name: STDERR=
arguments.description: Outputs the following statistic: STDERR<=name> Standard deviation of linear predictor; default variable name: "StdErr" STDERR(NOBLUP)<=name> Standard deviation of marginal linear predictor; default variable name: "StdErrPA" STDERR(ILINK)<=name> Standard deviation of mean; default variable name: "StdErr"

arguments.name: STUDENT=
arguments.description: Outputs the following statistic: STUDENT<=name> Studentized residual; default variable name: "Student"

arguments.name: UCL=
arguments.description: Outputs the following statistic: UCL<=name> Upper prediction limit for linear predictor; default variable name: "UCL" UCL(NOBLUP)<=name> Upper confidence limit for marginal linear predictor; default variable name: "UCLPA" UCL(ILINK)<=name> Upper prediction limit for mean; default variable name: "UCLMu"

arguments.name: VARIANCE=
arguments.description: Outputs the following statistic: VARIANCE<=name> Conditional variance of pseudo-data; default variable name: "Variance" VARIANCE(NOBLUP)<=name> Marginal variance of pseudo-data; default variable name: "VariancePA" VARIANCE(ILINK)<=name> Conditional variance of response; default variable name: "Variance_Dep"

arguments.name: ALLSTATS
arguments.description: Requests that all statistics are computed.

arguments.name: ALPHA=
arguments.description: Determines the coverage probability for two-sided confidence and prediction intervals. The coverage probability is computed as 1-number. The value of number must be between 0 and 1; the default is 0.05.

arguments.name: CPSEUDO
arguments.description: Changes the way in which marginal residuals are computed when model parameters are estimated by pseudo-likelihood methods.

arguments.name: DERIVATIVES
arguments.description: Adds derivatives of model quantities to the output data set.

arguments.name: NOMISS
arguments.description: Requests that records be written to the output data only for those observations that were used in the analysis.

arguments.name: NOUNIQUE
arguments.description: Requests that names not be made unique in the case of naming conflicts.

arguments.name: NOVAR
arguments.description: Requests that variables from the input data set not be added to the output data set.

arguments.name: OBSCAT
arguments.description: Requests that in models for multinomial data statistics be written to the output data set only for the response level that corresponds to the observed level of the observation.

arguments.name: SYMBOLS
arguments.description: Adds to the output data set computed variables that are defined or referenced in the program.

statements.name: PARMS
statements.description: The PARMS statement specifies initial values for the covariance or scale parameters, or it requests a grid search over several values of these parameters in generalized linear mixed models.

arguments.name: HOLD=
arguments.description: Specifies which parameter values PROC GLIMMIX should hold equal to the specified values.

arguments.name: LOWERB=
arguments.description: Enables you to specify lower boundary constraints for the covariance or scale parameters.

arguments.name: NOBOUND
arguments.description: Requests the removal of boundary constraints on covariance and scale parameters in mixed models.

arguments.name: NOITER
arguments.description: Requests that no optimization of the covariance parameters be performed.

arguments.name: PARMSDATA=
arguments.description: Reads in covariance parameter values from a SAS data set.

arguments.name: UPPERB=
arguments.description: Enables you to specify upper boundary constraints on the covariance parameters. The value-list specification is a list of numbers or missing values (.) separated by commas.

statements.name: PUT
statements.description: The PUT statement writes text data to the current output file.

arguments.name: _PAGE_
arguments.description: Outputs any pending line data and moves to the top of the next page.

statements.name: RANDOM
statements.description: the RANDOM statement defines the Z matrix of the mixed model, the random effects in the Gamma vector, the structure of G, and the structure of R.

arguments.name: ALPHA=
arguments.description: Requests that a t-type confidence interval with confidence level 1-number be constructed for the predictors of G-side random effects in this statement. The value of number must be between 0 and 1; the default is 0.05

arguments.name: CL
arguments.description: Requests that t-type confidence limits be constructed for each of the predictors of random effects in this statement.

arguments.name: G
arguments.description: Requests that the estimated G matrix be displayed for G-side random effects associated with this RANDOM statement. PROC GLIMMIX displays blanks for values that are 0.

arguments.name: GC
arguments.description: Displays the lower-triangular Cholesky root of the estimated G matrix for G-side random effects.

arguments.name: GCI
arguments.description: Displays the inverse Cholesky root of the estimated G matrix for G-side random effects.

arguments.name: GCOORD=
arguments.description: Determines how the GLIMMIX procedure associates coordinates for TYPE=SP() covariance structures with effect levels for G-side random effects.

arguments.name: LAST
arguments.description: Determines the coordinates for a level of the random effect from the last observation associated with the level.

arguments.name: FIRST
arguments.description: Determines the coordinate from the first observation.

arguments.name: MEAN
arguments.description: Determines the coordinate from the average of the observations.

arguments.name: GCORR
arguments.description: Displays the correlation matrix that corresponds to the estimated G matrix for G-side random effects.

arguments.name: GI
arguments.description: Displays the inverse of the estimated G matrix for G-side random effects.

arguments.name: GROUP=
arguments.description: Identifies groups by which to vary the covariance parameters.

arguments.name: KNOTINFO
arguments.description: Displays the number and coordinates of the knots as determined by the KNOTMETHOD= option.

arguments.name: KNOTMAX=
arguments.description: Provides upper limits for the values of random effects used in the construction of knots for TYPE=RSMOOTH.

arguments.name: KNOTMETHOD=
arguments.description: Determines the method for constructing knots for the radial smoother fit with the TYPE=RSMOOTH covariance structure and the TYPE=PSPLINE covariance structure.

arguments.name: KDTREE
arguments.description: Syntax: KNOTMETHOD=KDTREE<(tree-options)> where tree-options can take the following values: BUCKET=number determines the bucket size b. A larger bucket size will result in fewer knots. KNOTTYPE=type specifies whether the knots are based on vertices of the tree cells or the centroid. NEAREST specifies that knot coordinates are the coordinates of the nearest neighbor of either the centroid or vertex of the cell, as determined by the KNOTTYPE= suboption. TREEINFO displays details about the construction of the k-d tree, such as the cell splits and the split values.

arguments.name: EQUAL
arguments.description: Syntax: KNOTMETHOD=EQUAL<(number-list)> This option enables you to define a regular grid of knots. By default, PROC GLIMMIX constructs 10 knots for one-dimensional smooths and 5 knots in each dimension for smoothing in higher dimensions.

arguments.name: DATA
arguments.description: Syntax: KNOTMETHOD=DATA(SAS-data-set) You can specify a data set that contains variables whose values give the knot coordinates with the KNOTMETHOD=DATA option. The data set must contain numeric variables with the same name as the radial smoothing random-effects. PROC GLIMMIX uses only the unique knot coordinates in the knot data set. This option is useful to provide knot coordinates different from those that can be produced from a k-d tree.

arguments.name: KNOTMIN=
arguments.description: Provides lower limits for the values of random effects used in the construction of knots for TYPE=RSMOOTH.

arguments.name: LDATA=
arguments.description: Reads the coefficient matrices A1, ..., Aq for the TYPE=LIN(q) option.

arguments.name: NOFULLZ
arguments.description: Eliminates the columns in Z corresponding to missing levels of random effects involving CLASS variables. By default, these columns are included in Z. It is sufficient to specify the NOFULLZ option in any RANDOM statement.

arguments.name: RESIDUAL
arguments.description: Specifies that the random effects listed in this statement be R-side effects.

arguments.name: SOLUTION
arguments.description: Requests that the solution for the random-effects parameters be produced.

arguments.name: SUBJECT=
arguments.description: Identifies the subjects in your mixed model. Complete independence is assumed across subjects; thus, for the RANDOM statement, the SUBJECT= option produces a block-diagonal structure in G with identical blocks.

arguments.name: TYPE=
arguments.description: Specifies the covariance structure of G for G-side effects and the covariance structure of R for R-side effects.
arguments.help: TYPE=ANTE(1) | AR(1) | ARH(1) | ARMA(1,1) | CHOL<(q)> | CS | CSH | FA(q) | FA0(q) | HF | LIN(q) | PSPLINE | RSMOOTH | SIMPLE | SP(EXP)(c-list) | SP(GAU)(c-list) | SP(MAT)(c-list) | SP(POW)(c-list) | SP(POWA)(c-list) | SP(SPH)(c-list) | TOEP | TOEP(q) | TOEPH<(q)> | UN<(q)> | UNR<(q)> | VC*covariance-structure*

arguments.name: ANTE(1)
arguments.description: Specifies a first-order ante-dependence structure (Kenward 1987; Patel 1991) parameterized in terms of variances and correlation parameters.

arguments.name: AR(1)
arguments.description: Specifies a first-order autoregressive structure.

arguments.name: ARH(1)
arguments.description: Specifies a heterogeneous first-order autoregressive structure.

arguments.name: ARMA(1,1)
arguments.description: Specifies the first-order autoregressive moving-average structure

arguments.name: CHOL<(q)>
arguments.description: Specifies an unstructured variance-covariance matrix parameterized through its Cholesky root.

arguments.name: CS
arguments.description: Specifies the compound-symmetry structure, which has constant variance and constant covariance.

arguments.name: CSH
arguments.description: Specifies the heterogeneous compound-symmetry structure, which is an equi-correlation structure but allows for different variances.

arguments.name: FA(q)
arguments.description: Specifies the factor-analytic structure with q factors (Jennrich and Schluchter 1986).

arguments.name: FA0(q)
arguments.description: Specifies a factor-analytic structure with q factors.

arguments.name: HF
arguments.description: Specifies a covariance structure that satisfies the general Huynh-Feldt condition (Huynh and Feldt 1970).

arguments.name: LIN(q)
arguments.description: Specifies a general linear covariance structure with q parameters.

arguments.name: PSPLINE
arguments.description: Requests that PROC GLIMMIX form a β-spline basis and fits a penalized β-spline (P-spline, Eilers and Marx 1996) with random spline coefficients. Syntax: TYPE=PSPLINE<(options)> You can specify the following options for TYPE=PSPLINE: DEGREE= specifies the degree of the β-spline. The default is d=3. DIFFORDER= specifies the order of the differencing matrix Dr. The default and maximum is r=3.

arguments.name: RSMOOTH
arguments.description: Specifies a radial smoother covariance structure for G-side random effects. Syntax: TYPE=RSMOOTH<(m|NOLOG> The NOLOG option removes the log{h-ik} and log{d-kp} terms from the computation of the Z and Ω matrices when nr is even; this yields invariance under rescaling of the coordinates.

arguments.name: SIMPLE
arguments.description: Is an alias for TYPE=VC.

arguments.name: SP(EXP)(c-list)
arguments.description: Models an exponential spatial or temporal covariance structure, where the covariance between two observations depends on a distance metric dij.

arguments.name: SP(GAU)(c-list)
arguments.description: Models a gaussian covariance structure.

arguments.name: SP(MAT)(c-list)
arguments.description: Models a covariance structure in the Matérn class of covariance functions (Matérn 1986).

arguments.name: SP(POW)(c-list)
arguments.description: Models a power covariance structure.

arguments.name: SP(POWA)(c-list)
arguments.description: Models an anisotropic power covariance structure in k dimensions, provided that the coordinate list c-list has k elements.

arguments.name: SP(SPH)(c-list)
arguments.description: Models a spherical covariance structure.

arguments.name: TOEP
arguments.description: Models a Toeplitz covariance structure.

arguments.name: TOEP(q)
arguments.description: Specifies a banded Toeplitz structure.

arguments.name: TOEPH<(q)>
arguments.description: Models a Toeplitz covariance structure. Syntax: TYPE=TOEPH<(q)>

arguments.name: UN<(q)>
arguments.description: Specifies a completely general (unstructured) covariance matrix parameterized directly in terms of variances and covariances.

arguments.name: UNR<(q)>
arguments.description: Specifies a completely general (unstructured) covariance matrix parameterized in terms of variances and correlations.

arguments.name: VC
arguments.description: Specifies standard variance components and is the default structure for both G-side and R-side covariance structures.

arguments.name: V
arguments.description: Requests that blocks of the estimated V matrix be displayed. You can optionally use the value-list specification, which indicates the subjects for which blocks of V are to be displayed.

arguments.name: VC
arguments.description: Displays the Cholesky root of the blocks of the estimated V matrix. The value-list specification is the same as in the V= option.

arguments.name: VCI
arguments.description: Displays the inverse of the Cholesky root of the blocks of the estimated V matrix. The value-list specification is the same as in the V= option.

arguments.name: VCORR
arguments.description: Displays the correlation matrix corresponding to the blocks of the estimated V matrix. The value-list specification is the same as in the V= option.

arguments.name: VI
arguments.description: Displays the inverse of the blocks of the estimated V matrix. The value-list specification is the same as in the V= option.

arguments.name: WEIGHT
arguments.description: Specifies a variable to be used as the weight for the units at the current level in a weighted multilevel model. If a weight variable is not specified in the WEIGHT option, a weight of 1 is used.

statements.name: RETURN
statements.description: Stops executing statements at the current point in the DATA step and returns to a predetermined point in the step.

statements.name: SLICE
statements.description: The SLICE statement provides a general mechanism for performing a partitioned analysis of the LS-means for an interaction. This analysis is also known as an analysis of simple effects. The SLICE statement uses the same options as the LSMEANS statement.

arguments.name: ADJDFE=
arguments.description: Specifies how denominator degrees of freedom are determined when p-values and confidence limits are adjusted for multiple comparisons with the ADJUST= option.

arguments.name: SOURCE
arguments.description: The denominator degrees of freedom for multiplicity-adjusted results are the denominator degrees of freedom for the LS-mean effect in the "Type III Tests of Fixed Effects" table.

arguments.name: ROW
arguments.description: Useful if you want multiplicity adjustments to take into account that denominator degrees of freedom are not constant across LS-mean differences.

arguments.name: ADJUST=
arguments.description: Requests a multiple comparison adjustment for the p-values and confidence limits for the differences of LS-means.
arguments.help: ADJUST=BON | DUNNETT | NELSON | SCHEFFE | SIDAK | SIMULATE | SMM | TUKEY

arguments.name: BON
arguments.description: Bonferroni adjustment

arguments.name: DUNNETT
arguments.description: Dunnett adjustment (in which the procedure analyzes all differences with a control level)

arguments.name: NELSON
arguments.description: Nelson adjustment (in which ANOM differences are taken)

arguments.name: SCHEFFE
arguments.description: Scheffe's adjustment

arguments.name: SIDAK
arguments.description: Sidak adjustment

arguments.name: SIMULATE
arguments.description: Computes adjusted p-values and confidence limits from the simulated distribution of the maximum or maximum absolute value of a multivariate t random vector. Syntax: SIMULATE<(simoptions)> You can specify the following simoptions in parentheses after the ADJUST=SIMULATE option. ACC=value specifies the target accuracy radius γ of a 100(1-ε)% confidence interval for the true probability content of the estimated (1-α)th quantile. The default value is ACC=0.005. CVADJUST specifies that the quantile should be estimated by the control variate adjustment method of Hsu and Nelson (1998) instead of simply as the quantile of the simulated sample. EPS=value specifies the value ε for a 100(1-ε)% confidence interval for the true probability content of the estimated (1-α)th quantile. NSAMP=n specifies the sample size for the simulation. REPORT specifies that a report on the simulation should be displayed, including a listing of the parameters, such as γ, ε, and α, as well as an analysis of various methods for estimating or approximating the quantile. SEED=number specifies an integer used to start the pseudo-random number generator for the simulation.

arguments.name: SMM
arguments.description: SMM adjustment

arguments.name: TUKEY
arguments.description: If your data are unbalanced, PROC GLIMMIX uses the approximation described in Kramer (1956) and identifies the adjustment as "Tukey-Kramer" in the results.

arguments.name: ALPHA=
arguments.description: Requests that a t-type confidence interval be constructed for each of the LS-means with confidence level (1-number)x100%. The value of number must be between 0 and 1; the default value is 0.05, corresponding to a 95% confidence interval.

arguments.name: AT=
arguments.description: Enables you to modify the values of the covariates used in computing LS-means.

arguments.name: BYLEVEL
arguments.description: Requests that separate margins be computed for each level of the LSMEANS effect.

arguments.name: CL
arguments.description: Requests that t-type confidence limits be constructed for each of the LS-means. The confidence level is 0.95 by default; this can be changed with the ALPHA= option.

arguments.name: CORR
arguments.description: Displays the estimated correlation matrix of the least squares means as part of the "Least Squares Means" table.

arguments.name: COV
arguments.description: Displays the estimated covariance matrix of the least squares means as part of the "Least Squares Means" table.

arguments.name: DF=
arguments.description: Specifies the degrees of freedom for the t test and confidence limits.

arguments.name: DIFF=
arguments.description: Requests that differences of the LS-means be displayed.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: Requests all pairwise differences, and it is the default.

arguments.name: ANOM
arguments.description: Requests differences between each LS-mean and the average LS-mean, as in the analysis of means (Ott 1967).

arguments.name: CONTROL
arguments.description: Requests the differences with a control, which, by default, is the first level of each of the specified LSMEANS effects.

arguments.name: CONTROLL
arguments.description: Tests whether the noncontrol levels are significantly smaller than the control; the upper confidence limits for the control minus the noncontrol levels are considered to be infinity and are displayed as missing.

arguments.name: CONTROLU
arguments.description: Tests whether the noncontrol levels are significantly larger than the control; the upper confidence limits for the noncontrol levels minus the control are considered to be infinity and are displayed as missing.

arguments.name: E
arguments.description: Requests that the L matrix coefficients for all LSMEANS effects be displayed.

arguments.name: ILINK
arguments.description: Requests that estimates and their standard errors in the "Least Squares Means" table also be reported on the scale of the mean (the inverse linked scale).

arguments.name: LINES
arguments.description: Presents results of comparisons between all pairs of least squares means by listing the means in descending order and indicating nonsignificant subsets by line segments beside the corresponding LS-means.

arguments.name: NOF
arguments.description: Suppresses the F test for testing the mutual equality of the estimable functions in the partition.

arguments.name: OBSMARGINS
arguments.description: Specifies a potentially different weighting scheme for the computation of LS-means coefficients.

arguments.name: ODDS
arguments.description: Requests that in models with logit, cumulative logit, and generalized logit link function the odds of the levels of the fixed effects are reported.

arguments.name: ODDSRATIO
arguments.description: Requests that LS-mean differences (DIFF, ADJUST= options) and simple effect comparisons (SLICEDIFF option) are also reported in terms of odds ratios.

arguments.name: PLOT=
arguments.description: Requests that least squares means related graphics are produced via ODS Graphics, provided that the ODS GRAPHICS statement has been specified and the plot request does not conflict with other options in the LSMEANS statement.
arguments.help: PLOT=ALL | ANOMPLOT | CONTROLPLOT | DIFFPLOT | MEANPLOT | NONE

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: Requests that the default plots corresponding to this LSMEANS statement be produced.

arguments.name: ANOMPLOT
arguments.description: Requests an analysis of means display in which least squares means are compared to an average least squares mean.

arguments.name: CONTROLPLOT
arguments.description: Requests a display in which least squares means are visually compared against a reference level.

arguments.name: DIFFPLOT
arguments.description: Requests a display of all pairwise least squares mean differences and their significance. Syntax: DIFFPLOT<(diffplot-options)> You can specify the following diffplot-options: ABS all line segments are shown on the same side of the reference line. NOABS separates comparisons according to the sign of the difference. CENTER marks the center point for each comparison. NOLINES suppresses the display of the line segments that represent the confidence bounds for the differences of the least squares means. The NOLINES option implies the CENTER option.

arguments.name: MEANPLOT
arguments.description: Requests displays of the least squares means. Syntax: MEANPLOT<(meanplot-options)> The following meanplot-options control the display of the least squares means: ASCENDING displays the least squares means in ascending order. This option has no effect if means are sliced or displayed in separate plots. CL displays upper and lower confidence limits for the least squares means. By default, 95% limits are drawn. CLBAND displays confidence limits as bands. This option implies the JOIN option. DESCENDING displays the least squares means in descending order. This option has no effect if means are sliced or displayed in separate plots. ILINK requests that means (and confidence limits) are displayed on the inverse linked scale. JOIN | CONNECT connects the least squares means with lines. This option is implied by the CLBAND option. SLICEBY=fixed-effect specifies an effect by which to group the means in a single plot. PLOTBY=fixed-effect specifies an effect by which to break interaction plots into separate displays.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Requests that no plots be produced.

arguments.name: SINGULAR=
arguments.description: Tunes the estimability checking as documented for the CONTRAST statement.

arguments.name: SLICE=
arguments.description: Specifies effects by which to partition interaction LSMEANS effects.

arguments.name: SLICEDIFF=
arguments.description: Requests that differences of simple effects be constructed and tested against zero.

arguments.name: SLICEDIFFTYPE=
arguments.description: Determines the type of simple effect differences produced with the SLICEDIFF= option.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: Requests all simple effects differences, and it is the default.

arguments.name: CONTROL
arguments.description: Requests the differences with a control, which, by default, is the first level of each of the specified LSMEANS effects.

arguments.name: CONTROLL
arguments.description: Tests whether the noncontrol levels are significantly smaller than the control; the upper confidence limits for the control minus the noncontrol levels are considered to be infinity and are displayed as missing.

arguments.name: CONTROLU
arguments.description: Tests whether the noncontrol levels are significantly larger than the control; the upper confidence limits for the noncontrol levels minus the control are considered to be infinity and are displayed as missing.

arguments.name: STEPDOWN=
arguments.description: Requests that multiple comparison adjustments for the p-values of LS-mean differences be further adjusted in a step-down fashion. You can specify the following step-down options in parentheses: MAXTIME=n specifies the time (in seconds) to spend computing the maximal logically consistent sequential subsets of equality hypotheses for TYPE=LOGICAL. REPORT specifies that a report on the step-down adjustment should be displayed, including a listing of the sequential subsets (Westfall 1997) and, for ADJUST=SIMULATE, the step-down simulation results.

statements.name: STOP
statements.description: The STOP statement halts the execution of all statements that contain it, including DO statements and other control or looping statements. Execution continues with the next top-level source statement.

statements.name: STORE
statements.description: The STORE statement requests that the procedure save the context and results of the statistical analysis. The resulting item store is a binary file format that cannot be modified. The contents of the item store can be processed with the PLM procedure. The item-store-name is a usual one- or two-level SAS name, like the names that are used for SAS data sets. If you specify a one-level name, then the item store resides in the WORK library and is deleted at the end of the SAS session. Since item stores usually are used to perform postprocessing tasks, typical usage specifies a two-level name of the form libname.membername. If an item store by the same name as specified in the STORE statement already exists, the existing store is replaced.

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: The item-store-name is a usual one- or two-level SAS name, like the names that are used for SAS data sets. If you specify a one-level name, then the item store resides in the WORK library and is deleted at the end of the SAS session.

arguments.name: LABEL=
arguments.description: Adds a custom label. When the PLM procedure processes an item store, the label appears in the PROC PLM output along with other identifying information.

statements.name: WEIGHT
statements.description: The WEIGHT statement replaces R with (W^-1/2)(RW^-1/2), where W is a diagonal matrix containing the weights. Observations with nonpositive or missing weights are not included in the resulting PROC GLIMMIX analysis. If a WEIGHT statement is not included, all observations used in the analysis are assigned a weight of 1.
